bodyItems.detailText: A standardized question is one that’s been asked before in other, independent studies. By using the same question in these studies, researchers can compare the data and gain insights. Standardized questions appear in some Research app surveys, including this one.

steps.text:
Answer a few demographic questions.

These questions help researchers understand how your ethnicity, where you live, and other factors relate to the other data you contribute.

This information can be shared with the studies you enroll in if you give your permission.

bodyItems.detailText: A standardized question is one that’s been asked before in other, independent studies. By using the same question in this study, researchers can compare the studies and gain insights.
This question was adapted from the U.S. Census Current Population Survey.

formItems.text: Which of the following best describes your current employment situation?

formItems.detailText:
Think of this ladder as representing where people stand in the country you live in.

At the top of the ladder are the people who are the best off – those who have the most money, the most education, and the most respected jobs. At the bottom are the people who are the worst off – those who have the least money, least education, the least respected jobs, or no job. The higher up you are on this ladder, the closer you are to the people at the very top; the lower you are, the closer you are to the people at the very bottom.

Please select where you think you stand at this time in your life relative to other people around you.

bodyItems.detailText: A standardized question is one that’s been asked before in other, independent studies. By using the same question in this study, researchers can compare the studies and gain insights.
This question is the MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status, which is a standardized question that research has shown is related to overall health.

formItems.text: Where would you place yourself on this ladder?
